cons: You're not paid enough to motivate you to take the initiative and go above and beyond. Plus, there seems to be no room for growth within the organization.

pros: The faculty culture seems so much better than it used to be. There seems to have been an exodus of toxic or unhealthy faculty members.

pros: This position allows you to foster community and care for the students in an intentional way.

job_title: Director of Operations in Pasadena, CA
pros: There is a lot of room to grow in your career and people are kind and caring.
cons: The staff is second class to the organization, faculty are given all of the attention, benefits, and care. HR has no form of training for managers or teams or any type of company culture. If someone is laid off, you are expected to take on their work with no further compensation. There is a clear pay gap between gender and race.

pros: A good place to work.
cons: Lots of institutional changes. Everything going online.

pros: good, good, good, good, good

review_title: Systemic Issues and Lack of Accountability
pros:
Benefits (especially insurance) are great
Competent HR
Most people are friendly
cons:
Inept senior management
Unwilling to discipline or keep accountable senior admins who fail in their job responsibilities
Hostile to minorities with systemic issues of racism and bigotry
If you are not faculty, your opinion has little meaning
Financial mismanagement for years has left the school on the brink of collapse with the failed move to Pomona being the most recent example. If any senior admin had taken a few minutes to read the school's documents that concern their relationship with the city of Pasadena, the whole debacle could have been avoided. Senior admin claim they did not know that was coming, but that is due to their ineptitude
Poor treatment of employees through underpaying, unclear guidelines for success, lack of transparency about the state of the school's finances, and lack of recognition of student and staff voices

pros: Work pace is largely leisurely.  A lot of nice people with good intentions work there.
cons: The overall ethos and mood there has been negative for quite some time. This is a result of multiple rounds of lay-offs of entry-level and middle management positions, while hiring senior-level positions. Senior leadership have been struggling to effectively lead through what is a significant time of change for the institution. It looks as if they are trying to change the core of what they offer and what they are offering does not look too promising. Generally, there is little to no investment in the professional development of employees.

review_title: Not what it used to be...
pros: Great mission; some good people still left
cons: The past six years under the current president has been an unmitigated disaster in terms of organizational culture and brain drain. President runs the seminary like a senior pastor of a mega-church with no accountability. Is great at rhetoric, coming up with shiny new ideas/vision, and good soundbite; is horrible at following through and takes ZERO responsibility for poor decisions made. Nepotism is rampant, with president brining in people he likes regardless of their competency. Launches the key initiative of his presidency by hiring four presbyterian pastors with no higher-ed background into senior leader positions. Few years later, half of them have left and the other two are in different positions. Yet, no accountability. Meanwhile, lower level staff with low wages are laid off constantly. For past 4-5 years running, constant layoffs and budget cuts, promising publicly to reign in spending and change the way Fuller operates; meanwhile spending expands by $8 million. Yet NO ACCOUNTABILITY. The HR is biased and the organization is retaliatory. Don't believe me? Just go and talk to some folks who have been working there for a while.

pros:
1. Benefits: I think its great. Fuller makes it easier to afford healthcare and dental care. 
2. Environment: I haven't met anyone I dislike! I really enjoy the Christian atmosphere and the access to the library's resources.
3. Work-Life Balance: Best perk for me. I hardly have to do OT and I can go home right as I finish up my 8-hour shift.
cons:
1. Moving Soon: Fuller is moving to Pomona, so anyone hoping to stay in Pasadena would find this disheartening.
2. Lower Pay than Industry Average: I personally think Fuller makes up for this by its benefits packages, but I understand that some people just want higher wages.
3. Restructuring: Fuller is currently restructuring as it prepares for its move to Pomona.

pros: The work life balance at Fuller is wonderful. I get my work done, put in my hours and have the flexibility I need when I need it. I'm able to learn and grow as a person as well as in my professional career. Fuller is a place that I can become the person I want to be in my career and life. I can ask hard questions, work on amazing projects, and see them to fruition.
cons: The wakes of the previous management structure are still rippling across Fullers landscape. This can sometimes be counter productive and counter intuitive for getting things done, but doesn't take away from the mission or values at Fuller. As a Graduate school, there aren't many opportunities for non-academia related positions to move up, at least in the technical fields.

job_title: Project Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The work environment at Fuller is very congenial and neighborly.  I didn't want to leave the school because I had such a great coworkers.  I still keep in touch with them, even though I've left the seminary.
cons: Fuller Theological Seminary is currently in very deep debt. I was laid off due to the financial instability of the school.  They are in talks to move the school from Pasadena to Pomona.

pros: The staff and administrators are truly united by a strong sense of mission. Largely, managers are understanding not only of a needful work/life balance but also a work/life/church/class balance as the case often is. Those who work for Fuller are committed, and it shows. Summers have recently also featured paid reduced (i.e., four-day) workweeks. The administration goes to lengths to show its appreciation for employees.
cons: Communication is a perennial problem, and silos abound, despite recent intentions from senior administration. Change is constant and not always coordinated among the relevant divisions and departments. This results in a fair deal of work at cross-purposes, playing catch-up and general inefficiency.

pros:
Decent PTO for part-time employees. Great work-life balance (at least in my department); you are not expected to work after you leave the office. 

Great sense of professional community.
cons: Expect to do way more in your position than you should reasonably be expected to. Because of recent restructuring, employees wear way too many hats and do not get paid accordingly.

review_title: Underpaid but the insurance is good
job_title: Student Records Coordinator in Pasadena, CA
pros:
- You will likely have a decent work-life balance
- Generally good relationships with supervisors and colleagues
- Excellent health/vision insurance 
- Excellent Dental insurance
- 2 weeks vacation pay
- Excellent sick leave
cons:
- Below average salaries
- No cost of living raises
- Excessive number of unnecessary Directors and Executive Directors
- Mismanagement of resources

job_title: Office of Advancement in Pasadena, CA
pros: Beautiful campus, excellent location. Pasadena is stunning
cons: I experienced institutionalized racism and sexism when I was there. It was an extremely hostile work environment for me. I was heavily scrutinized, treated differently, spoken to differently, passed over for jobs that I was more than qualified for that my white counterparts with a lot less experience than me were given. It was a toxic work environment with gossip, back-biting and strife. The institution needs a complete overhaul. Because the organization is so disorganized, people are often sitting at their desks with nothing to do and it's dehumanizing. Working there is not recommended.

job_title: Live Event Technician in Pasadena, CA
pros: It was a great opportunity to work while going to school full time. Working events also allowed me to listen to many awesome lectures and continue my education all while working a soundboard.
cons: Limited scale for events. It's a small school, so there wasn't tons of room to be stretched in new technology.

pros: Strong collegial relationships and good working environment. I enjoyed the academic environment and shared sense of purpose and professional calling.
cons: Stratified organizational structure can make it difficult to get things done, at times. However, most leadership are approachable and collaboration and input from middle management is appreciated.

pros: In the summers, often you get Fridays off. Also the campus is very beautiful.
cons: Where to begin, it's difficult to image that this school will still exist in 20 years, the financial and personal mismanagement is so rampant. I have never met people in my life that will talk about such lofty goals and then be so disrespectful to the support staff.
